comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: Interesting.  That looks something like a modern scissor lift used for overhead maintenance purposes.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Original glass negative at PhM - [http://www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/5570142283/] Or from.ph/376720

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/32162360@N00] This I would imagine was the way the overhead wires were erected in the pre-electric era, ie the conversion from steam to electric. Certainly calls for more research to establish a date.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/johncowper] This tower wagon (or ones very similar)  was being used at The Spit, maybe to install or repair the wires c.1900. See comments here -

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/5393624233/]

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/32162360@N00]  One the system was converted to electric power the authority used motor lorries to do the job (the power was turned off). I'll see if I have a picture somewhere!
